Detexi ergo super ipsum iterum, et non cessaui incidere os particulatim, et conari restaurationem eius: et non est restauratum, donec incidi ex osse circiter palmum unum, et extraxi illud cum medulla sua.	I therefore uncovered it again above that and did not stop cutting away the bone bit by bit, and tried to restore it; and it is not restored, until I cut off from the bone about a hand's breadth, and extracted it with its marrow.
Deinde restauraui ipsum cum medicinis, et consolidatum est uelociter, et sanatum: et non fuit necessaria haec iteratio in operatione eius, et sectione ipsius, nisi propter dispositionem debilitatis infirmi, et paucitatem tolerantiae eius, et timorem meum super ipsum de morte: quoniam accidebat ei in omnibus horis ex superfluitate euacuationis syncopis mala.	Then I restored it with medicines, and it was quickly consolidated and healed; and this iteration was not necessary for its operation and section, except on account of the debilitated patient's weakness, his lack of tolerance, and my fear for him regarding death: because it was happening to him in every hour from excessive evacuation.
Sanatus est ergo sanatione integra: et nata est in loco ossis caro dura, et bona facta est dispositio in corpore suo, et rediit uirtus eius: et conuersatus est in dispositionibus suis: et non fecit ei contrarietatem in ambulatione nocumentum omnino.	He was therefore healed with complete healing: and firm and good flesh grew in the place of the bone, and a good arrangement was made in his body, and his strength returned: and he reverted to his usual habits: and he did not experience any harm or inconvenience at all in his walking.
Si autem os eminens in loco corporis iam fractum est: tunc oportet ut serres ipsum, secundum hunc modum: et est: ut accipias ligamentum, et stringe ipsum in extremitate ossis eminentis: et praecipe alicui, qui extendat ipsum ad sursum: et pone ligamentum aliud ex lana grossius ligamento primo.	If the prominent bone is already broken in its place in the body: then it is necessary to repair it, in this manner: and is: take a ligament, and tie it at the extremity of the prominent bone: and order someone to stretch it upwards: and place another ligament made of coarse wool from the first ligament.
Deinde liga ipsum super carne, quae est suh osse: et extende extremitatem eius, ut trahas carnem ad inferiora: et tu detegis carnem super locum quem uis serrare, ut non laedat Serra carnem.	Then bind it above the flesh which is under the bone: and stretch the extremity of it, so that you draw the flesh down to the lower parts: and you take away the flesh from the place which you want to sew, so that the suture does not hurt the flesh.
Pone lignum, aut tabulam sub osse inferius decenter: quoniam quando facis illud, non prohibetur quin secet carnem corruptam.	Place a piece of wood or a board under the bone below moderately: because when you do this, it does not prevent the corrupted flesh from being cut.
Et oportet ut sit Serratura super locum corruptum parumper, ut non sit in concauitate ossis corruptio: et non appareat in apparitione sua sensui, et cogat ad Serraturam sui uice alia.	And it is necessary for the suture to be over the corrupted place a little bit, so that the corruption of the bone does not occur in concavity; and it should not appear in its appearance to the sense, and make another suture in its place.
Quod si os est corruptum, et non est eminens, imo continuatur pars eius cum parte: et corruptio est in medio eius, aut in parte ipsius: tunc detege carnem ab omnibus partibus totam.	What if the bone is corrupted and is not prominent, but rather continues with its part; and corruption is in the middle of it or in a part of it: then remove all flesh from around the entire area.
Deinde pone lignum inferius.	Then place wood underneath.
Postea serra illud ex parte prima, ubi est corruptio, donec continuetur Serratura ex parte altera: et sit Serratura secundum longitudinem a corruptione parumper, secundum quod diximus.	Afterwards sew that from the first part where there is corruption, until the suture is continued on the other side; and let the suture be according to the length from the corruption a little bit, as we said.
Quod si corruptio est in iunctura, incide ipsam iuncturam corruptam, et serra os ubi continuatur ex parte altera.	What if the corruption is at the joint, cut off the corrupted joint and sew the bone where it continues on the other side.
Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	If however the corruption is in the continuation of two joints, then there is no skill except abrasion.
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	What if the corruption is in the pit of the hand or in the pit of the foot: then the matter in that case is very difficult.
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	But it is necessary for you to inquire into the corruption and see how it appears to you.
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	And smooth it out, and clean the same according to whatever arrangement is possible for you, and with whatever skill you have; when it does not make opposition to you, Vein, or Nerve.
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	And know that the saws and files for cutting these bones are many, according to the position of the bones, and their preparation, and their thickness, and subtlety, and magnitude, and smallness, and hardness, and rarity.
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Therefore it is necessary to prepare the suitable instrument for every kind of operation.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	And know that these operations are significant to you according to the type of instrument you need, when with you is a long study.
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And knowledge of the methods of this art is a testimony to the methods of illnesses: then indeed you will find through yourself what fits each weakness from instruments.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	And I am setting forth for you at the end of this chapter the number of instruments which you will use as examples on which to cut and proof by which to test other things.
Forma Serrae.	Saw shape.
Forma alterius Serrae.	Shape of another saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	Shape of the other saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	Shape of another saw.
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This shape of a saw is depicted, let it be well-made.
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Let the upper part of its bow be made, and its edge sharp from iron: and its handle from boxwood, and let it be well-made pyramidal.
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	Shape of a file for joints.
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	Let the head of this file be, according to the shape of the head of a star-shaped awl; and its points, according to the shape of the points of an emery stone.
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	And it is not suitable except that they rub against this file when the joints are worn out, or a large and great bone.
Forma maioris Rasorii.	Shape of a larger file.
Forma medii Rasorii.	Form of the Middle Razor.
Forma Rasorii lati.	The shape of a broad razor.
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	The shape of a razor in which there is hollowing.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	The shape of another, thin razor.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	The shape of another, curved-tipped razor.
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	The shape of a small, thin file-like razor.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	The shape of a razor with which bones are cut.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	The shape also of a large razor.
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This resembles a saw, and the end is like a file: it is shown in many places for scraping bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	The shape of a razor that is suitable for scraping what has been pierced from bones.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	Its end is triangular, with sharp tips.
Fit ex Indi.	It is made in India.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And similarly all that we have said should be made from Razors, Files, and Sawblades.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	Of cutting off extremities and sawing bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	Head 89.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	They putrefy because of an external cause or an internal one.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	Therefore, when you have treated the corruption with medicines and the treatment does not help: and you see the corruption occurring in a member which does not respond to anything: then it is necessary that you cut off that member up to where the corruption follows, so that the sick person may escape through that member from death or from the greater defect of the member.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign that this occurs is that the member turns black until it becomes putrid: which fire has consumed, or has rotted after becoming black: until the putrefaction is cut off up to where that member follows, and spreads throughout the entire body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Therefore, proceed with the cutting off of that member, and similarly if the cause of corruption is due to the striking of certain venomous things, such as the sea scorpion, viper, or adder, and similar ones.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If therefore corruption or striking is at the tip of the finger, then cut off the finger and do not give space to corruption to spread until it reaches the rest of the hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And similarly if it happens in the hand, then cut off the hand from the wrist and do not give space to corruption until it reaches the forearm.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it spreads into him, then cut off the arm at the elbow joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	But if corruption passes through and you see him around the elbow: then death is at hand for that person.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And to apply something beyond that in healing is a quantity of power.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And similarly do this for the foot, when corruption invades the toe; then cut it off at one of the joints. And if it reaches into the instep of the foot, then cut off the entire foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	But if it ascends to the knee, then cut off the leg at the knee joint.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	And if corruption has already reached above the knee, then there is no skill in it except giving up and leaving the sick person to death.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the method of cutting off a limb or cutting it is to tighten the ligament on the lower side that you wish to cut off: and then tighten another ligament above the place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And have the assistant stretch one ligament down lower: and have the assistant stretch another ligament up higher above.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you separate the flesh that is between the two ligaments with a broad spatula, until all the flesh is exposed.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then it should be cut off or cut.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	And it is necessary that you place a linen cloth around all parts and not touch the healthy area with the saw: and the sick person will suffer added harm and a warm abscess.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	If bleeding occurs internally while you are working, then cauterize the place quickly: or place some powder on top that absorbs blood.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your treatment until it is complete.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind the wounded limb with a suitable ligament and care for it until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I will tell you what happened to a man on his foot, the same thing that is happening to him.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	What is this? Because a blackening occurred on his foot, similar to a burning by fire, and that corruption first affected his finger until it spread throughout his entire foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	Therefore the man took care of himself after he saw the corruption affecting his member with its madness, which he discovered through pain and burning; and it happened to him at the joint, and he was healed.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after a long time had passed, the same corruption occurred on his index finger of his hand.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	So he came to me, and I attempted to remove the excess with him by applying medicines after purifying his body; and the excess was not removed, and it began to move to another finger: until corruption spread throughout his hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	So he called me to cut open his hand; and I did not want to do it, hoping that the excess would be removed through itself; and I also feared death for him during the opening of his hand.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	Because the man's strength was above his condition.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	After that, he lost hope in me and returned to his land; and he came back to me about it because he was advised, and cut open the entire hand of his own accord; and he was healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And I did not bring this story forth except to be a help for what falls under the category of this kind of illness; and so that it may be a signification by which one may signify and according to which one should act.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	Chapters on the treatment of sinuses, and the quality of cleansing with medicines.
Caput XC.	Chapter 90.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When an abscess occurs in certain fleshy members and the space of the abscess is prolonged until it forms a collection of pus: then it bursts or perforates and what is inside it comes out through the pus, and the location remains empty as if it were a vessel; and the skin that covers it is like a piece of cloth that has been worn thin. And it does not reach its final state of corruption nor imprint on bone, muscle, or ligament: it merits being called a Sinus; and it is not called Fistula. However, if the space of this abscess is prolonged until corruption imprints on one of these members, then it is called Fistula, or sinus.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And the treatment for it is to cut off that skin entirely as it has rotted; and especially when it has been worn thin and made like a piece of cloth. And you may rely on this because it will not adhere to the location due to its own corruption.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	But if you hope that the skin will adhere and does not result from that last stage of corruption; and if there is a thickness on the skin from flesh, then treat it with a clyster, and it is to consider it with respect to the sinus.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	Then if it is large and the pus that is emitted from it has a foul odor: then clysterize it with a medicine from Egypt, which is a mixture of vinegar, oil, and zinc powder, with equal parts, gathered in a vessel: and let them be decocted over fire until the medicine turns red: and come to the thickness of honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take from it what you need: and dissolve it with water and honey, and clysterize it with that into the sinus: and tie off its opening, and let the medicine stay in it for a period of two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then extract it with expression: make it that way for days until the sinus is cleansed and the foul odor is removed.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And sometimes clysterize it with ash water when this medicine is not available to you; and it is, that you take the ash of vine wood or ash from ilex trees: and throw it over her.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then smear it on and cover it with a poultice until you are confident that the sinus has been cleansed.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	If the patient is not tolerating the Egyptian remedy nor water of ashes, then cover him with a poultice made from water and honey to which some crushed ziniar has been added.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or cover him with a poultice made from honey and wine mixed together, since it is known that the property of honey is to cleanse and purify: and wine makes the sinus stick together, especially when there is an excess of dryness and bitterness.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	When you have done this a few times and are confident that the corruption of the sinus has been removed: then cover him with a poultice made from what produces flesh growth in it.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And it is, as you take from the plaster a diaphanizing substance; and dissolve it with rose oil and astringent wine: or cover him with a poultice made from certain medicines and other ointments, whose properties I have written in the treatise on ointments.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	If the orifice of the sinus is narrow and does not admit a catheter for a poultice: then dilate it with a iron instrument for a little while: or place in it a linen cloth wrapped in Egyptian ointment or basilikon ointment, until it has been dilated.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And similarly if the orifice is also large, then gather up its lips with a suture and let go from it as much as the catheter can enter without addition.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And similarly if the orifice through which pus flows is elevated towards the upper parts: then cut it at a lower point which is in it, so that the pus may flow from it downwards: because when the pus is compressed in the depth of the sinus, it prevents flesh from growing in it.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	If it is not possible for you to cut the sinus around its lower part as you wish: then try to prepare the limb with a preparation by which the pus may flow from it with ease, according to what is prepared for you.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	To prevent anything from sticking to it from pus entirely: and receive medicinal congees placed on the mark, suitable for what you wish.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And stretch them over a linen cloth.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And let the cloth be of such a size that there may be communication throughout the sinus.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then cut with forceps directly into the orifice of the sinus, making the opening a little larger than the orifice of the sinus.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then spread a soft ointment on another cloth, according to the size of the opening; and place it over it, far from the orifice of the sinus, so that the discharge of pus may be alleviated from it: and do not remove the cloth until after several days.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	But the one that is on the orifice of the sinus, you remove at every hour, so that what has accumulated in it from pus may flow out; and to know whether the flowing substance is much, a little, digested, or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And when you have done this again, examine the site of the sinus itself, whether its lord feels pain in it or not; and whether there is abscess in it or not.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	When therefore your treatment proceeds thus, and you see the material that flows out on the orifice of the sinus, then you will know that the sinus has already adhered or is approaching adhesion: then therefore dissolve it in the morning, or on the third day; and when you dissolve the wound, then change the cloth to another one and renew the ointment.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	But if a subtle pus flows out from the sinus after a long period, then do not despair of its adhesion, for its healing is approaching, since there are people who delay the formation of flesh in their wounds, and there are those who act contrary to that.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	But if a undigested pus flows out from the sinus after many days, then you will know that the sinus does not adhere.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	If therefore the adhesion of the sinus is delayed and its substance is prolonged: then add to the drying remedies what physicians truly make, so that they are humid in their substance and dry in their power, just as diaphoretic ointment when an excess of addition is made from aloes.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from the last part of the treatment is this: that you take diaphoretic ointment and dissolve it with rose oil, and sprinkle it over old wine equal to its substance.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then mix it with that, and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And now this makes a similar action when you do not have diaphoretic ointment, honey, by cooking it until it thickens, and using it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Or take myrrh, and aloe, and frankincense: grind all together, and powder it over honey while it is still warm.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then spread the mixture over the cloth, and tie it over the sinus: and then tie with honey that you have cooked until thickened: and powder over it the kind of powder, and put it on the cloth, and tie it.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And sometimes administer it with Aristolochia longa, and the roots of the Heavenly Lily, and is Lily: and the flour of a herb, and Centaury.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use them simple or combined, grind them together, and sift it: and powder over the honey that I narrated, and use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	But if the sinus's condition prolongs and is not healed by this treatment: then you will know that there is corruption deep within it: or already making an impression on the bones, or in other hard members, or ligaments: then cure it with Fistula treatments, as was previously mentioned.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	About the treatment of Panaritis and worn-out nails, and the addition of finger cuts and sections.
Caput XCI.	Chapter 91.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	Painful swelling is a pustule that arises under the nail of the thumb or foot: and perhaps it arises in other fingers.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	When therefore the condition of this thing is prolonged and its cure is neglected, and a pustule arises with heat: or it becomes corrupted and emits pus, until it corrupts the root of the nail: and perhaps it corrupts it entirely, and perhaps the corruption reaches to the bone, until it has a foul odor: and the end of the finger becomes wide, and its color becomes dark.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	When therefore you are treating it as we said in the division, and your treatment is not effective: then it is necessary that you cut off with iron all the excess that remains from the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the wound afterwards.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	For cauterization is very helpful.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	If however the bone is sound, and the nail also sound, and the added flesh of the nail already compresses the flesh to the inside, and begins to pierce it, and hurt it: then it is necessary that you place a subtle Radicum under the angle of the nail which pierces the flesh, and push it upwards: and cut through the flesh with ease, and put over what remains of the flesh from medicines that burn and corrode, until the whole thing is removed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointments, until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	If however the corruption has already taken root in the bone, then it is necessary that you cut off that bone and remove it: for it will never heal as long as the corrupted bone remains.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	What if you see a corruption and gangrene spreading to the finger, then cut it off at one of the joints, according to what has been previously remembered about it.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it, until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	If however fingernail attrition or percussion occurs, and severe pain accompanies it, then it is necessary that you bleed the patient first.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then cut the nail with a sharp Spathiumuli cross-section from above downwards.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And take care that the cutting does not reach the flesh which is under the nail, for you would cause severe suffering to an innocent person through that above, and it will be a reason for adding flesh to the place.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then care for the place with what calms pain.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	The added finger that is born on some hands of men, perhaps is all fleshy: and perhaps there are bones in some of them, and perhaps there is a nail on it: and some of them are born at the root of the joint, or its birth is in certain knots of the finger.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	Therefore, the one that is born in certain knots of the finger does not move: and the one that is born at the joint of the finger, perhaps moves.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	Therefore, the fleshly one among them is easy to cut.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	Which is, that you should cut it at its root with a broad Spathium.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	But the cure of one whose birth is at the joint of the root is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	Therefore, abstain from cutting it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	In that one who is born at the end of the fingers, then it is necessary to cut into its first flesh with a rounded incision up to the bone.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Then saw through the bone with one of those saws that are suitable for it.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	However, the union that occurs between fingers one against the other, often happens either through the birth of a person, that is, it grows with him, or from the consolidation of a wound, or from burning by fire, and similar things.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	Therefore, you should cut that union until the fingers return to their natural shape.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then place between them linen or cloths soaked in rose oil: so that they do not consolidate quickly, and separate between them: or place between them a thin plate of lead, until the place is consolidated as it should be.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And similarly if consolidation occurs in some fingers with the palm, then cut off that consolidation, according to how it is prepared and suits the shape of the member.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	Chapter on Cutting Off Defects.
Caput XCII.	Head 92.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	There are swollen, thickened, and distended veins which occur from excessive melancholic humors that happen in many parts of the body: and most often they occur in legs, especially in those who walk or work a lot, and carry heavy loads.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	Therefore it is necessary to administer a purgation of the body with black chalk several times with strong scratching.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then let bloodletting be done on the patient's basilica vein.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	However, their treatment with iron is according to two methods.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	One of them is that they should be cut and the black blood drawn out.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	And the other method is to elevate the vein and draw it all out.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	The cutting of it is according to this method.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	Wrap the leg first with hot water a great deal, until the thick, clotted blood dissolves.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then bind the lame leg with a bandage from the upper part of the hip down to the lower part of the knee.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then cut the vein at one place, or two places, or three wide incisions.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then elevate, that is, draw out the blood from your hand from the lower part of the leg up to the top, and it is necessary to let the patient bleed first.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then cut off the nail right down to the bottom: until a quantity of blood emerges that you see is sufficient and which the patient's strength can tolerate.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	After that, bind it up and advise him to abstain from foods that produce black bile: and repeat the evacuation and bloodletting when the veins are full and it harms the patient.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	The elevation of it is according to this method.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	Remove the crippled man's crutches if there are many hairs in them.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then introduce him into a bath; or immerse his leg in hot water with him until it becomes red and the veins are filled: or exercise him in strong exercise, if there is no bath present, until the limb warms up.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then cut the skin along the straight course of the vein throughout its length: or at its end near the knee, or at its lower part near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the cut with forceps and scrape the vein clean from all parts until it is visible to the sense; and at its appearance, you will see it becoming red, then declining to blackness.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When it comes out of the cut, you will see it white as if it were a cord.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then introduce Radix under it until when it is lifted up and emerges from the cut: suspend it with a blind forceps, gently.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then cut another section near that section three fingerbreadths away.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then scrape the cut from the upper part of the vein until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then lift it up with Radix as you did, and suspend it with another forceps as you did at first.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then cut another section, or multiple sections if needed.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then lift it up and cut off the last section at the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then pull it out to the section that is above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And do this until you pull it out from the upper or higher sections altogether, when it emerges entirely: then cut it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	If it does not obey you to pull out and lift up: then introduce a needle with a strong thread twice as long, and bind it, and pull it out: or introduce Radix under it: and turn your hand in all directions until it emerges.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	And beware, lest it be cut.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if it is cut, it will be difficult for you to lift it strongly, and harm from it will come upon the patient.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	When therefore you have taken it all out: then place a soaked cloth of wool on the wound site, submerged in wine and rose oil, or oil: and care for it until it heals.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	And if it is a vitiligo that has contracted and has twisting and turning to parts, and it is not as we said according to straightness: then it is necessary for you to cut into it on all sides of its twisting and the places of its encircling.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then suspend it with a hook until you lift it all out: and beware not to cut into the vein or wound on it: for it will be difficult for you to lift or pull it out.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Therefore, conserve your prudence.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	The Form of Cutting by Which Vitiligo Heals.
Forma Vncini caeci.	The Form of the Blind Knot.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It is not curved like the other knots, nor is it sharp at its extremity, so that it does not cut a vein: and it has a large, gentle curvature: because if it were thin, it would cut a vein with its thinness: indeed let there be excessive thickness, as we said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	On the Extraction of the Vein of the Thigh.
Caput XCIII.	Chapter 93.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This Vein is generated in the thighs of people living in hot lands, such as Alizegi, and Arabian land, and in dry, hot lands with little vegetation, that is, where no grass or tree grows.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it is generated in other parts of the body besides the thighs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	And its generation indeed is from the putrefaction that occurs under the skin, just as it happens to serpents and ascaride worms inside the body, and worms generated between the skin and flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of the beginning of this vein's outcome is that a violent inflammation occurs in the leg.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then the place is irrigated.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein begins to flow out from that area of irrigation, as if it were the root of a plant or an animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	So when its end appears from it, then you must wrap around it a piece of lead, whose weight is one and a half drachmas to two drachmas, up to the node, and let the lead hang down from the leg.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	Whenever then something emerges from it to the outside, wrap that in lead and tie it off.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	But if it is prolonged greatly, then cut off a part of it and wrap up the remainder.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And do not cut it at its root before it has emerged completely.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	Because if you cut it, it contracts and enters into the flesh; and causes an aposteme, and putridity in the place, and a bad ulcer.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore it is necessary to handle it gently and draw it out gradually, until it emerges from its last part, and nothing remains of it in the body; and from this very Vein, in some people, there flows a matter which is five palms and ten digits long.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And now it has reached me, because it flowed out of a man for twenty palms.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	But if you are cut on the hour of your medical treatment: then insert a catheter into its orifice and pierce it with a long instrument, along with the body, until all that is in it is evacuated from the material: and administer putrefaction to the place with medicines for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then cure the wound by curing the apostemes.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And this Vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears at the junction of the foot, or on the foot itself: and it has many openings, and a branch emerges from every opening.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Therefore, treat it as we have said in division, and with what has been added before.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	About the removal of worms generated under the skin, and it is called Ox-like Distress.
Caput XCIIII.	Chapter 94.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This Distress is called Ox-like Distress in a certain land among us; therefore, because it often happens to oxen, and it is a small worm that is born between the skin and flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And it wanders throughout the body, ascending and descending; and it is revealed to the sense during its movement from member to member, until it breaks wherever it breaks through the skin, and emerges.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And its generation is from the putrefaction of some humors.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	Just like worms and serpents, that is, earthworms, and roundworms in the belly.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And be feared from its evil.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	Because when it goes through the body and ascends to the head, and reaches a place: then perhaps it opens there, and emerges, and destroys an eye: and that happens many times.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	When therefore you wish to cure it and extract it, then that is not done except through its wandering and the appearance of itself to the sense.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	Therefore, you must bind what is above it and what is below it with a strong constricting bandage.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then cut above it, and extract it.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	And if it burrows into the flesh and you cannot find it: then place a cautery above the place with fire, until it dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And what is feared most is its corruption, which corrupts the eye, as we said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	If however you see it has already reached the head near the eye, then bind below it the eyebrow with a good constriction.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then cut above it, and extract it.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	It is necessary that the sick person uses cleansing of his body with medicines dissolving foul bad humors.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And he should beware for himself against foods causing corruption.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	About the treatment of Nakir's illness.
Caput XCV.	Chapter 95.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This illness is called Nakir in our land; and it is a pain that occurs in some members, then it changes from member to member.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And I myself have indeed seen him, according to how I tell you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I was called to a sick woman in certain villages.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And she showed me her arm, and I saw a small swelling in the vein of the arm.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after staying for one hour, I saw a swelling moving with the pulse, like a worm, ascending to her shoulder more quickly than it can be, so that it is like living silver when it runs from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	Therefore the pain departed from that place and was fixed in the shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then I sat for one hour, and it ran through the rest of the body until it reached another arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	Then she told me that it was revolving throughout her entire body, according to what I saw.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	I was amazed therefore at the speed of its changes from member to member.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And I myself had not seen this illness with my own eyes in such a way before that.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	However I have seen many who find pain changing from member to member, and I did not see it with my own eyes as I saw it in the woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	And I do not think that it is not, except that the woman was one of those who are from dry and arid bodies with detected veins: hence it appears to my sense that this windiness has been changed.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	And it is necessary that they do not appear according to this reason in those who are delicate and have moist bodies with hidden veins.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	When you wish to treat it and the patient feels that pain: then if it appears to your eye, as we said, then bind above it quickly and beneath it swiftly: and cut above it until the swelling subsides: and cauterize the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	But if you do not see it with your own eyes: then treat it by excision of the body and by that which drives out swellings, and expel them with fetid poultices and with poultices made from serapium and similar things.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	On the Extraction of Arrows.
Caput XCVI.	Chapter 96.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows are distinguished according to their kinds and according to the places where they fall from the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	And their diversity is this: because some of them have large points, and small; and hollow, and blunt.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And some of them have three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And some of them have tongues.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And some of them have stars.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	Those that fall according to the members are two-fold.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	Or else the members are from the main concave members, such as the brain, and the heart, and the liver, and the lung, and the kidney, and the intestines, and the bladder, and those like them.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	When therefore it falls on one of these members and you see signs of death which I will tell you later, then it is necessary to remove the arrow from that member, for death follows him who has it in many situations.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when you do not see those bad signs and the arrow is not hidden in the depth of the member, then remove it and treat the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	For the signs of the brain are: when an arrow falls on it and pierces the skull, and the siphac that is above the brain comes out; namely, because there occurs a sudden faintness, and dimness of vision, and vertigo, and redness in the eyes, and inflation, and redness of the tongue, and spasm, and a mixture of intellect, and vomiting of bile.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood will flow from the nose, or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps speech is cut off, and voice is destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And moisture like whitewash comes out from the place of the wound.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And pus like fatty meat juice flows out from it.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If then these signs appear to you, then refrain from treatment, and extract the arrow if there is no discharge.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of the arrow when it falls in the heart are: that it is near the left breast; and it feels as if it were fixed in a hard substance, not in an empty space.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the arrow's movement is similar to the pulse; and black blood flows from the wound.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And then follows numbness in the extremities, and cold sweat, and fainting.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	Know therefore that death is surely approaching.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	And the sign of the arrow when it wounds the lung is: that foam-like blood flows from the wound; and the vessels that follow the neck, become inflamed, and change color to a sickly hue.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And he expires with a great, deep breath; and seeks the support of cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	Which if the arrow falls in the membrane that is in the chest: then it is near to the small ribs; and a great panting occurs with violent pain, with a sigh: and all the upper limb members are moved.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if the arrow falls in the stomach, then perhaps something undigested from food will flow out from the wound.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if the arrow falls into the Womb and is stuck there: something like dung will flow out from the wound, or a yellowish discharge, or an intestine that has already been torn.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	Therefore there is no hope for its cure, nor for extracting the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	Which if the arrow falls into the Bladder and urine flows out: and something proceeds from it to the outside, and the pain is more severe over the sick person: then you will know that it is mortal.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	The remaining limbs, such as the face, neck, and throat, and the scapula, and the assistant, and the thoracic vertebrae, and the cruris, and those similar to them from limbs are saluted according to many dispositions: when an arrow does not find an artery or a nerve; and it is not a poisonous arrow.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I will tell you what I saw to be about these arrows, so that you may signify it for your cure.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	What is this? Because a certain man had an arrow fall into the root of his nose and the lacrimal gland of his eye.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	I therefore removed it from him on the other side, under his ear fat; and he was healed, and no harm befell his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I removed another arrow from a Jew, which had fallen into the fatty part of his eye below the lower eyelid; and the arrow was already hidden, and I did not manage to remove anything from it except for its small tip with which it was stuck in its wood: and the arrow was a large one from the bows of the Turks, with a gentle iron, without ears.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	And therefore the Jew was healed, and no evil befell his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I removed another arrow from a Christian's throat.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And the arrow was Arab, and it is that one with ears.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	So I followed above it between two gullet-ribs; and already it was submerged in his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	I therefore worked carefully with it until I removed it: and the Christian was healed.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I removed another arrow from a man who had fallen into his belly; and we thought that he would die from it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	Afterwards, then, thirty days had passed for him and nothing had changed in his condition; I followed above the arrow: and I worked carefully on it, and removed it: and he was healed, and no evil befell him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And I saw a man whose arrow had fallen on his back, and the wound had been closed over it.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	Afterwards, therefore, seven years having passed, the arrow was discharged from its root in his hip joint.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And I saw a woman whose arrow had fallen into her womb, and the wound was closed over it, and the arrow remained within her; and nothing of her physical functions was changed, and the woman did not find any harm in her natural bodily processes.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And I saw another man whose arrow had fallen on his face; and the wound was closed, and it remained without causing him much pain; and similar things are numerous.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I extracted the arrow from a man who was one of the king's chief men, which had fallen into his nose and had already begun to incline towards the right side; and the arrow was entirely concealed.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	I was therefore summoned for his treatment after the arrow's fall, until three days had passed.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	I found then the wound of the arrow to be very tightly bound.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	I therefore questioned him with a fine probe, and did not feel it; but he himself found a puncture and pain under his ear on the right side.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	I therefore hoped that that puncture was from the end of the arrow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	I therefore applied a dressing to the place with a dressing that had drawing and digestive power, trusting in myself that the place would suppurate and I would see a sign of the arrow appearing for me to cut above it; and nothing happened in the place that would indicate that the arrow had reached there.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	I therefore applied the dressing to him day after day for many days; and nothing happened, and the wound was closed in the meantime: and he remained weak from its extraction for a space of days, until one day he felt the arrow inside his nose.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me this.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	So I put a sharp and corroding medicine on it for many days until it was opened; and when I probed it gently, and felt the tip of the arrow subtly attached to the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then I added to the opening of the wound with that sharp medicine until the tip of the arrow appeared visibly to us; and after this time, a period of about four months passed.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then after the wound had been enlarged and it was possible for me to insert a forceps into it and move it, but it did not yield to exit: then I did not cease to subtilize and engineer over it with various methods, until on a certain day I extracted it with well-made forceps, according to their shape at the end of the chapter.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I restored the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And doctors indeed judge that the nasal cartilage is not restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	So I restored it and the wound was consolidated and the patient recovered with entire health, nor did anything harm him at all.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I tell you the quality of extracting some arrows: so that you may put it as a rule and signification for what I did not say.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	Because the parts and distinctions of this art are not comprehended by narration: nor does that book comprehend it, and a wise craftsman compares little with much: and with what is present, about what is absent: and he finds a new operation and a new instrument in the descents of external things of this art when they occur.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say that arrows do not exit from the members in which they are fixed, unless according to two modes.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or by attraction from the place where it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or by the contrary part of the other side.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which exits from where it entered is either an arrow proceeding into a fleshy place and is attracted and exits.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	If it does not obey the exit at the hour when it falls: then it is necessary to release it some days until the flesh surrounding it becomes rotten: and let its attraction and egress be eased.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And similarly, if it is stuck in bone and does not obey you at the exit, then release it also some days: and repeat it with attraction and motion every day, until it exits.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	If it does not obey you at the exit after days, then it is necessary to pierce in the surrounding bone with a fine awl from all sides, until the splinters are widened.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then draw it out and extract it.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	But if the arrow is fixed in the skull bone and has already entered one of the cerebral ventricles, and some of those symptoms I mentioned appear from the patient: then abstain from drawing out the arrow and release it, until its aftermath subsides after days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrow reaches the sifach, then death is not prolonged for him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed except in the body of bone only and does not penetrate as far as the sifach, and the patient remains weak for some days and nothing from those accidents happens to him: then attempt at drawing out the arrow and extracting it.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	But if it is fixed very firmly and does not obey you at the drawing out: then apply a file to the surrounding area of the arrow, as I told you before: then take care of the wound, until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	But if the arrow is already concealed in the body and hidden from sense perception: then search for it with probes.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	But if you feel it, then draw it out with certain instruments that are suitable for drawing it out.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	But if you cannot pull it out over it, due to the constriction of the wound and the length of the arrow deep inside: and there is no bone, nor nerve, nor vein nearby: then find a way over it, until the wound opens up and it becomes possible to extract the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	If the patient has ears that are affected, then free the fixed flesh from all parts of those ears, by any means you can manage to do so, and if it is not possible to lift the flesh above the breaking point of the ears and their twisting until it goes away.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And when you are extracting the arrow, wherever it is located, then use a twisting motion with your hand and forceps to all parts until it comes out: and with very fine subtlety, so that the arrow does not break and its extraction becomes difficult for you.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	If you cannot extract it within an hour, then leave it for a few days until the decayed matter surrounding it has rotted.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then reiterate the extraction: for it will be relieved by means of a poultice. If, however, it causes bleeding contrary to your expectation, then administer what we have said in its own chapter: and preserve your strength from incision of the vein, nerve, or cord.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And administer your skill in any way possible for the extraction of the arrow: and let it be with ease, and quietness, or slowness, and firmness, as I have told you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And it is necessary that you make the arrow pull weakly as if an invalid was pulling, according to the shape and form of how the arrow was situated at the moment of its being shot.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	Because it is more beneficial.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	If however it is not possible for you to do that, then administer what is possible for you according to the shapes.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.
